awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: TRAIN (TRAnsfer to Interdisciplinary Natural sciences): A Community College-University Consortium to Increase Community College Student Transfer and Success
awd_abstract_narration:
The TRAnsfer to Interdisciplinary Natural sciences (TRAIN) program supports students from community college through graduation from Arizona State University's New College.  TRAIN students begin with scholarships and a robust set of support structures at the community college, which follow them seamlessly through transfer to ASU.  Students are recruited from Phoenix, South Mountain, and Glendale Community Colleges (all HSIs), where approximately 85% identify as individuals traditionally underrepresented in STEM.   In addition to scholarship support, students benefit from engagement with faculty mentors, specialized advising, peer mentoring, tutoring, research experiences, and participation in cohort-based activities.  Authentic, career-focused experiences underpin the cohort formation; students are offered various opportunities, such as undergraduate research, internships, volunteer opportunities and field trips.  Students blog about these authentic experiences, relating them to their educational and career development.  Weekly blog comments by students and faculty mentors keep the cohort connected and help to develop a robust peer-teaching and support network. 
                
The TRAIN program will add to the collective knowledge in STEM education by utilizing a value-added model of programmatic analysis which will analyze the unique challenges faced by students underrepresented in STEM, and determine how interventions and support structures impact diverse students differently.  A cost/benefit analysis of the support structures by sub-population will be undertaken and an analysis conducted to determine which yield the best returns on investment.  Broader impacts of TRAIN include the construction, evaluation and improved understanding of an innovative transfer pipeline between the nation's largest public university and one of its largest community college systems featuring several HSIs. This project could transform how community college students are supported during the attrition-prone transfer from two-year to four-year institutions.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: AZ Board of Regents on behalf of Arizona State University

por.por_cntn:
The Transfer to Interdisciplinary Natural & Mathematical Sciences (TraIN) project was funded through an NSF S-STEM Scholarship Award. The TraIN project was developed as a collaboration between Arizona State University and three Hispanic Serving Community Colleges (Glendale Community College, Phoenix College, and South Mountain Community College). The goal of the TraIN project was to identify meritorious STEM students and support them both at the community college and when they transferred to Arizona State University's West Valley campus to pursue a Bachelor's of Science. In addition to a generous needs-based scholarship up to $10,000 a year, students also received faculty academic mentoring, opportunities for research, internships, travel to conferences, field trips, peer mentoring, and other opportunities. These additional supports were designed to expand upon the existing supports ASU offers community college transfer students. Applicants to the TraIN program were selected based on their financial need, field of study, and commitment to earning a Bachelor's of Science in STEM. At ASU, a total of 61 students received scholarship support and, as of December 2023, 39 of them have graduated.  

Intellectual Merit:

The TraIN project was designed to follow best practices in supporting transfer students. Studying the concerns of TraIN students revealed what additional support would be needed beyond current best practices. To determine this, the TraIN knowledge generation team conducted semi-structured interviews and surveys with TraIN scholars. A thematic analysis of these interviews and surveys was then conducted focused on two questions: First, was the TraIN project effective in addressing known barriers to transferring? Second, what barriers and risks do transfer students still face? This analysis revealed the TraIN project helped address financial barriers, difficulty in credit articulation, and cultural barriers to university transfer. The analysis also identified new risks across academic, financial, social, logistical, and family-related domains, which were identified as having common themes related to complex bureaucratic processes and external circumstances beyond the students' control. These concerns were revealed to be related to the deep aversion of these students to take out student loans. A significant discovery was the importance of personal interactions, mentoring, and advising to students. These elements were highlighted by students as important parts in their transfer journey. 

The TraIN project also utilized a novel method of faculty academic mentoring.  Instead of assigning students a one-on-one mentor, students were placed in a cohort class. Each semester the class had a different instructor and a different topic.  The class topics were matched to faculty expertise and included: career goal setting, growth mindset, database use and construction, community, and leadership. Students in the cohort class met faculty from many different backgrounds and academic fields. The cohort class also encouraged transfer students to develop connections with other STEM transfer students. Introducing students to many faculty members and developing a community of students are two advantages the cohort class has over traditional mentoring.  Student and faculty feedback on the cohort class was positive. Students enjoyed learning about broad topics related to career and life success, getting to know faculty across the School, and meeting other STEM transfer students.

Broader Impacts:

All ASU TraIN students transferred from a community college, and are thus "non-traditional" students. The demographic split of the students is 64% female and 50% traditionally underrepresented in STEM.  Students' majors spanned the school, including forensic science, biology, statistics, applied math, applied computing, and environmental science. The TraIN program also funded undergraduate students to participate and present at a number of national and international research conferences. Students reported broad satisfaction with the program and indicated that they would have struggled to complete their four-year degree without the S-STEM support.  Students who graduated from the program are either pursuing additional graduate work in STEM fields or are employed in a variety of careers including medical laboratory or bench research, data analysis, software engineering, and federal environmental jobs.

The design and work of the TraIN project was shared at multiple venues focused on improving the transfer process from community college to University. These presentations included information on: barriers to the transfer process, ways to make STEM education more inclusive, and a panel of TraIN participants discussing their transfer journey.


 

 


Last Modified: 01/25/2024
Modified by: Pamela A Marshall
